text:
Q: "if let" assignment with specified data-type A:

"It's good practice for readable code to specify the actual data type" Is it though? "if the right side is complex or misleading" maybe it shouldn't be complex or misleading? Maybe there's a design issue here?

Q: How to disable AI autocomplete in VS Code? A:

In version 1.104, released in September 2025, VSCode has added the setting chat.disableAIFeatures which disables all built-in AI features when set to true.

{
  "chat.disableAIFeatures": true
}

– settings.json

Also see

  • Release notes | August 2025 (version 1.104) | microsoft/vscode-docs | github.com
  • How to disable all AI features in VSCode | shonebinu.com

Q: Write a shell script to find the largest among three numbers. Get user inputs and display the result A:

(I don't know why this old question has reappeared.)

Bash integers overflow when they get too big. Consider: echo $((12345678901234567890))

Here's a different approach that validates inputs and should handle arbitrary precision integers. I have assumed that input like 1 1 10 should succeed.

#!/bin/bash

# I use this because the question code does
# but I see other answers assume numbers on separate lines
read a b c

# validate input
if ! [[ $a,$b,$c, =~ ^(-?[0-9]+,){3}$ ]]; then
    echo "Malformed input"
    exit 1
fi

# if we get here, we have exactly 3 (possibly negative) integers

{ echo $a; echo $b; echo $c; } | sort -rn | uniq -c | {
    read count max
    case $count in
       3) echo "All the three numbers are equal" ;; 
       2) echo "I cannot figure out which number is largest" ;;
       1) echo "$max is largest number" ;;
    esac
}

sort can probably handle arbitrary precision but to be really safe use bc. For example:

echo "m=a=$a; b=$b; c=$c; if(b>m)m=b; if(c>m)m=c; (a==m)+(b==m)+(c==m); m" |
bc | {
    read count
    read max
    case ...
}

If bash were able to handle arbitrary precision, we could do:

(( max = b>a ? c>b ? c : b : a ))
(( count = (a==max)+(b==max)+(c==max) ))
case ...

Q: How to ensure that the input and output types of the function are not forgotten A:

I tend to place comments in the beginning of the Function to avoid forgetting what it does and what the Input and out puts are.

If you have a large code or project maybe some documentation can help as well for design and code structure.

Q: Install Lua in Linux and implement PHP Lua Extension A:

Solution for working php-lua extension for Ubuntu 22.04 and 24.04

apt update
apt install -y lua5.4 liblua5.4-dev php-pear php-dev
cd /root
git clone https://github.com/badoo/php-lua.git
cd php-lua
phpize
./configure --with-lua-version=5.4
make
cp modules/lua.so /usr/lib/php/20210902/lua.so

And after that:

Ubuntu 22.04

cp modules/lua.so /usr/lib/php/20210902/lua.so

# apache2

echo "extension=lua.so" > /etc/php/8.1/apache2/conf.d/20-lua.ini

# or nginx

echo "extension=lua.so" > /etc/php/8.1/fpm/conf.d/20-lua.ini

Ubuntu 24.04

cp modules/lua.so /usr/lib/php/20230831/lua.so

# apache2

echo "extension=lua.so" > /etc/php/8.3/apache2/conf.d/20-lua.ini

# or nginx

echo "extension=lua.so" > /etc/php/8.3/fpm/conf.d/20-lua.ini

Q: Ag grid vertical scroll issue A:

i think u must set "rowBuffer" property

rowBuffer: The number of rows rendered outside the scrollable viewable area the grid renders. Defaults to 20. Having a buffer means the grid will have rows ready to show as the user slowly scrolls vertically.

rowBuffer rowBuffer Example
